subject: Re: [junit] Re: A case for adding logging of assertions to junit

messageBody:
On Sat, Jun 14, 2008 at 8:32 PM, Mark Levison <mlevison@...> wrote:

>> ...or you could write smaller, more focused tests and learn something
>> about design.
>
> Is this a fair statement to make? You've never met Phil nor have you
> seen any of his test cases. You've no idea if he writes small focused
> tests or not.
>
> I think we can all learn to do a better job but I don't think this
> sort of reply serves either Phil or you well. Perhaps if this
> discussion were face to face that would have helped us all.

Having been on both sides of the debating table with JB, both agreeing
with and disagreeing with, I would just like to say that JB has always
been one to conduct himself with the highest level of manners and
integrity, both on this list and in other venues.

JB's specific question that appears to have triggered your concern
looks perfectly reasonable to me.

Please accept my apologies, but I had not been closely following this
conversation because logging within unit tests seems unnecessary. I
get a report when I run the tests using Ant, and as long as they all
pass, and have been updated as necessary, it shouldn't matter. But as
a moderator on this list, your comment caught my eye when approving
it.

Part of the challenge of email communication is that we get none of
the spontaneity of face to face discussions and none of the
side-channel meta-communications (gestures, facial expressions,
laughter etc etc), so please take extra care to allow for this known
drawback. I have never had the opportunity to meet JB in person, but
he and I have managed to have some excellent conversations over the
years both where I agreed and dis-agreed. One disagreement was so
strong, that he quoted me in his book as the opposite side for one of
his essays in the appendixes. Seems more than fair to me! :-)

Simon
(One of the JUnit list moderators)
